Article Efficient photoelectrochemical cell composed of Ni single atoms/P, N-doped amorphous NiFe2O4 as anode catalyst and Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O nanocubes as cathode catalyst for microplastic oxidation and CO2 reduction Hong-Rui Zhu a 1 Xi-Lun Wang b 1 Juan-Juan Zhao a Meng-Han Yin a Hui-Min Xu a Gao-Ren Li a * a College of Materials Science and Engineering, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610065, Sichuan, China College of Materials Science and Engineering Sichuan University Chengdu Sichuan 610065 China College of Materials Science and Engineering, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610065, Sichuan, China b School of Chemistry, Sun Yat-sen University, Guangzhou 510275, Guangdong, China School of Chemistry Sun Yat-sen University Guangzhou Guangdong 510275 China School of Chemistry, Sun Yat-sen University, Guangzhou 510275, Guangdong, China * Corresponding author. 1 Contributed to this work equally. Plastics are ubiquitous in human life and pose certain hazards to the environment and human body. The increasing amount of CO2 in the atmosphere will lead to the greenhouse effect. Therefore, it is urgent to treat microplastic waste and CO2 by using environmentally friendly and efficient technologies. In this work, we developed an efficient photoelectrocatalytic system composed of Ni single atoms (Ni SAs) supported by P, N-doped amorphous NiFe2O4 (Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO) as anode and Ag nanoparticles (Ag NPs) supported by CuO/Cu2O nanocubes (Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O NCs) as cathode for microplastic oxidation and CO2 reduction. The Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO was synthesized by calcination-H2 reduction method, and it achieved a Faraday efficiency of 93% for the oxidation reaction of poly (ethylene terephthalate) (PET) solution under AM 1.5 G light. As a photocathode, the synthesized Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O NCs was utilized to reduce CO2 to ethylene and CO at 1.5 V vs. RHE with selectivity of 42% and 55%, respectively. This work shows that the photoelectrocatalysis, as an environmentally friendly technology, is a feasible strategy for reducing the environmental and biological hazards of light plastics, as well as for efficient CO2 reduction. Graphical Abstract The picture is illustrated by placing Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO and Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O in a photoelectrocatalytic system to convert microplastic PET and exhaust CO2 into high-value products such as formic acid and ethylene. Keywords Ni single atom NiFe2O4 Photoelectrocatalysis Poly (ethylene terephthalate) plastics oxidation CO2 reduction reaction 1 Introduction Pollutants from the disposal of plastics are extremely harmful to the global environment and biological systems. Plastic waste present in the environment gradually breaks down over time into various forms, including microplastics with a diameter of less than 5 millimeters [1,2]. These microplastics are not only difficult to degrade but also cannot be effectively recycled [3]. Photoelectrocatalysis has the advantages of mild reaction conditions and environmental friendliness [4], which makes it a promising technology for plastic micro-waste resource treatment [5–8]. Polyethylene terephthalate (PET) is a typical polyester plastic that is readily hydrolyzed to other monomeric organics [9–11]. Recently, there have been reports that PET hydrolysis products, such as terephthalic acid (TA), ethylene glycol (EG) and phthalate esters, can be converted into formate or other high-value products by photocatalytic or electrocatalytic techniques. As TA and phthalate esters do not undergo any specific changes during the photocatalysis or electrocatalysis process, so EG is the main research object and the photocatalysis or electrocatalysis process is mainly dominated by the EG oxidation reaction (EGOR). Converting PET to TA, phthalate esters and EG by hydrolysis and then to high-value products such as formic acid by EGOR is the current thinking of most of the literature studying the conversion of PET. Therefore, the mechanism of this process is dominated by the study of photocatalytic or electrocatalytic technology for EGOR [12–14]. In recent years, electrocatalysis (EC) and photoelectrocatalytic (PEC) technology has attracted widespread attention. However, the mechanism of PEC technology in the EGOR process is not clear, so further in-depth research is needed [15,16]. In addition, carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR), an important pollutant conversion technology, can be utilized for PEC cathodic reaction [17–30]. Among the various products of CO2RR, ethylene is a promising organic compound, which is widely used in many industrial fields [31–36]. The EGOR and CO2RR can occur at the anode and cathode, respectively, so an efficient photoelectrochemical cell will greatly promote EGOR and CO2RR, which shows a broad application prospect [11,37,38]. Among the reported catalysts [39,40], Ni single atom-based catalysts are well suited for EGOR due to their properties such as excellent catalytic activity and high reaction efficiency. In addition, the spinel (AB2O4) materials are also suitable for EGOR due to their characteristics such as high catalytic activity, cheap production cost and easy synthesis. Currently, most of the non-precious metal (such as Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, etc.) single atom is in the form of M–N4 or M–N–C bonds [41–44]. The synthesis of single atom on spinel materials is particularly difficult because of the absence of C or N sites on the surface of materials. Based on our previous studies [45–52], the Ni single atom was successfully synthesized in this study by altering O atoms around Ni sites in the NiFe2O4 (NFO) structure through P and N co-doping, turning the NiO4 sites into Ni-N3-P sites. In addition, this process caused severe lattice distortion to NFO, leading to the formation of an amorphous structure. The novel photoelectrochemical cell (PEC) was constructed by using the synthesized Ni single atoms supported by P,N-doped amorphous NiFe2O4 (Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO) as an anode catalyst and Ag nanoparticles supported by CuO/Cu2O nanocubes (Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O NCs) as a cathode catalyst for microplastic oxidation and CO2 reduction. The results showed that in the PEC the light could effectively stimulate the generation of hydroxyl radicals and superoxide radicals on the surface of the anode catalyst, which further enhanced the catalytic activity. The Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO as anode catalyst can well promote EGOR, and its main products are formic acid, ethylene glycol, and TA. The Faraday efficiency of formic acid is as high as 93% at 1.42 V vs. RHE. The Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O NCs as cathode catalyst also can well promote CO2RR, and its main products are ethylene, CO, and H2. The CO2RR products are composed of 38% ethylene, 56% CO, and only 6% H2 at 1.5 V vs. RHE. The PEC system makes efficient use of both cathode and anode catalysts and offers promising ideas and applications for the efficient recovery of PET and the efficient reduction of CO2 in the future. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials All chemicals were used as received commercially. Nickel nitrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O), Ferric nitrate (Fe(NO3)3·9H2O), glucose (C6H12O6), urea (CH4N2O), sodium hypophosphite (NaH2PO2), Cupric sulfate (CuSO4), Sodium citrate (C6H5Na3O7), Sodium hydroxide (NaOH), Ascorbic acid (C6H8O6) and ethanol (C2H5OH) were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Reagent Co. Deionized water was used in the whole experiment. 2.2 Synthesis of Pre-NFO and C-NFO In a typical synthesis process, 0.8 g Ni(NO3)3·6H2O, 1.6 g Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, 0.8 g of glucose, and 0.8 g of urea were added to 30 mL of deionized water, stirred for 0.5 h, and subsequently reacted in an autoclave at 180 °C for 24 h. The reacted sample was washed three times with deionized water and ethanol and dried under vacuum overnight at 60 °C to obtain Pre-NFO. The Pre-NFO was annealed at 500 °C for 4 h under air atmosphere to obtain C-NFO. 2.3 Synthesis of P-NFO and Ni SAs/A-P-NFO In generally, 300 mg NaH2PO2 powder and above 50 mg C-NFO nanocrystals were placed in two crucibles, which are 20 cm apart in the tube. The two crucibles were then placed in the tube furnace, with the cell containing NaH2PO2 placed near the gas inlet of the furnace. Then the tube was heated to 300 °C with a rate of 5 °C min−1 for 3 h under the flowing N2 atmosphere. Finally, the system was cooled under a flowing N2 atmosphere and P-NFO nanocrystals were obtained. 300 mg of urea powder and more than 50 mg of P-NFO nanocrystals were placed in two crucibles, which were 20 cm apart in a test tube, and then the two crucibles were put into a tube furnace. Subsequently, Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO can be obtained by calcination at 500 °C under H2 atmosphere for 2 h. 2.4 Synthesis of Cu2O and Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O NCs In a typical synthesis process, 0.5 g CuSO4·5H2O, 0.29 g C6H5Na3O7, and 0.6 g NaOH were added to 200 mL of deionized water, stirred for 0.5 h, label the solution A, and subsequently added 0.528g C6H8O6 to 100 mL of deionized water, label it solution B, add solution B to A and stirred for 0.5 h. The reacted sample was washed three times with deionized water and ethanol and dried under vacuum overnight at 60 °C to obtain Cu2O nanocubes. Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O NCs nanoparticles were finally obtained by placing 10 mg of Cu2O nanoparticles in 10 mL of 1 mg mL−1 AgNO3 solution, stirring for half an hour, and then drying under vacuum at 60 °C overnight. 2.5 Physical characterizations The microstructures of various catalysts were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, TESCAN NMIRA3 LMU, CSU, USA) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Tecnai G2 F20 S-TWIN TMP, CSU, USA). The energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS, Oxford) profiles of the catalysts were also collected during TEM measurements. The X-ray diffraction patterns (XRD, Empyrean, Malvern Panalytical, Netherlands) with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) were recorded to investigate the phases composition of the catalysts at a scanning step of 5°min−1. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR, Bruker EMXPLUS, Bruker BioSpin, Germany) measurement was performed with a 100 kHz field modulation and a 100 G Sweep Width. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific K-Alpha, Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) measurements of the catalysts were conducted with S4 an Al Kα source. The contents of Fe and other impurities in catalysts were measured by inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometry (ICP-MS, Agilent 7700s, USA). The contents of Fe and Ni in the Ni SAC/A-P-N-NFO and Cu, Ag in the Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O NCs catalyst were conducted by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES, Agilent 7700s, USA). A 300 W xenon lamp (PLS-SME300E H1, Beijing Perfectlight Technology Co., Ltd.) equipped with an AM 1.5G filter was used as the light source, and the power density was fixed to be 100 mW cm–2. 2.6 Electrochemical analysis All the electrochemical measurements were performed at room temperature. The electrochemical tests were conducted on a CHI760 electrochemical workstation (CHI Instruments, Shanghai Chenhua Instrument Corp., China) in a three-electrode configuration composed of as-obtained catalyst (1.0 cm × 1.0 cm) as the working electrode, carbon rod as the counter electrode and Ag/AgCl (saturated KCl) electrode as the reference electrode. 3 Results and discussion NiFe2O4 was first synthesized by a hydrothermal method as shown in Fig. 1 . Then, P-doped NiFe2O4 (P-NFO) was obtained by placing both NaH2PO2 and NFO in a tube furnace and annealing under N2 atmosphere. Subsequently, P-NFO and urea were simultaneously placed in a tube furnace and annealed in a mixed H2/Ar atmosphere to obtain Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO. In the NiFe2O4 structure, Ni and Fe with surrounding O atoms exist as NiO4 and FeO6, respectively. The P,N co-doping changes the distribution of O atoms around the NiO4 sites, increases the O vacancy concentration, and results in the formation of the Ni-N3-P structure. In addition, it also changes the length of Ni-O bond, which made the Ni-O bond gradually become longer and weaker, and finally formed an amorphous structure. The synthesized Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO shows microparticles with wrinkled surface as shown in Fig. S1. TEM images of Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO are shown in Fig. 2(a) , and it can be observed that the lattice fringes show disorder, indicating that Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO is amorphous structure. Fig. 2(b) shows the AC-HAADF-STEM images of Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO, which shows that there are clear isolated bright spots, proving the formation of Ni single atom. Statistical analysis shows that the average size of Ni SAs is about 0.81 Å (Fig. 2(c)), and the atomic intensity profile in Fig. 2(d) shows similar intensity, indicating the successful introduction of atomically dispersed Ni sites. Fig. 2(e) shows XRD pattern of Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO, and the results show that Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO has no obvious characteristic peaks, proving the amorphous structure. Fig. 2(f) shows the EPR spectra of different samples, with Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO sample having the highest vacancy concentration. Due to H2 reduction, the concentration of O vacancies gradually increases, while the doping of P and N makes the concentration of O vacancies become higher. X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES), extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) and wavelet transform (WT) analyses were performed to reveal the existence of Ni single atom and how the doped P, N atoms change the local coordination environment and electronic configuration of the metal. As shown in Fig. 2(g), the position of Ni absorption edge of Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO is negatively shifted compared to Ni foil and P-NFO, which may be due to the doping of P and N that lowers the valence state of Ni, which is in the order of P-NFO > Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO > Ni foil. The main characteristic peak located at ~8351 eV in the Ni K-edge XANES spectrum is the white line peak, while the white line peak of Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO is weaker than that of P-NFO, indicating that after the introduction of P and N, Ni occupies a higher 3D orbital in Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO. In the Fourier transform EXAFS spectra of Ni (Fig. 2(h)), the P-NFO and Ni foil samples show distinct peaks characteristic of Ni–O and Ni–Ni bonds, respectively. For Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO, different characteristic peaks were observed compared to P-NFO and Ni foil. Compared to Ni foil sample, Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO does not show the characteristic peaks of Ni-Ni or Ni-Fe, indicating that no alloy or cluster structure is formed in Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO [53,54]. Compared to P-NFO, the characteristic Ni-Ni peaks with oxide structure were also not formed in Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO, and the shift of Ni–O bonds proved that some Ni–O bonds were replaced with Ni-N/P bonds. As shown in Fig. 2(i), for Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO, the wavelet transform analysis of EXAFS shows that the maximum value is located at 4.93 Å−1, which is related to the coordination of Ni with N/P. In contrast, for Ni foil and P-NFO, the maximum value corresponding to Ni-Ni coordination structure are 7.2 and 4.85 Å–1, respectively, and the maximum value corresponding to Ni-O coordination structure is 3.82 Å–1. This means that in P-NFO, there is no coordination structure of Ni single atom. Based on the above characterizations and analysis, for Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO, the Ni single atom should exist as Ni-N3-P in NFO. In addition, we believe that in the Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO structure, due to the large number of Ni atoms, it is not possible to convert all Ni atoms into the Ni SACs structure during the synthesis process. Therefore, the Ni sites that form Ni monoatomic structures only occupy a part of the structure, which means that not all Ni sites form Ni SACs. Meanwhile, the Ni sites that do not form Ni SACs form special coordination structures with a small amount of O. However, none of these chemical bonds form the Ni-N3-P structure, so no Ni SACs will appear. To investigate whether Fe forms single atom structure, the local coordination environment and electronic configuration of Fe in Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO have been revealed by XANES, EXAFS and WT analyses. XANES agrees with the results for Ni, indicating a decrease in the Fe valence state. The EXAFS results demonstrate that there are distinct Fe-O peaks and Fe-Fe peaks in P-NFO and Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO, whereas in Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO there is a significant shift of the two peaks compared to P-NFO due to P and N doping. The WT results indicate that there are also significant Fe-O peaks and Fe-Fe peaks in Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO. In summary, there is no single atom structure of Fe in Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO. Figs. S3(a)–(e) show the high-resolution XPS spectra of Ni 2p, Fe 2p, O 1s, P 2p and N 1s, respectively. The Ni 2p XPS spectrum shows two main peaks indicating the presence of trivalent nickel and the presence of Ni-P bonding [55,56]. The Ni 2p 1/2 and Ni 2p 3/2 peaks of Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO showed significant negative shifts of 0.45 and 0.72 eV, respectively, compared to P-NFO (Fig. S3(a)). It suggests that Ni in Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO adsorbs more electrons, has a lower valence state, and modulates the local charge of neighboring atoms. Fe 2p spectrum shows three main peaks at 711.3, 715.96 and 724.89 as shown in Fig. S3(b), indicating the presence of divalent/trivalent Fe [57]. Meanwhile, the Fe 2p 1/2 and Fe 2p 3/2 peaks of Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO also showed negative shifts of 0.29 and 0.32 eV compared to P-NFO (Fig. S3(b)). This phenomenon is the same principle as that of Ni 2p. In addition, in Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO, O vacancies are created by H2 reduction, so that P and N should take the place of O atom positions. And the substitution of O atom by N atom releases an extra valence electron. In order to maintain the overall charge balance, Ni may gain extra electrons from neighboring N and P and exist as Ni2+, and Fe may also exist as some Fe2+. The peak at near 532 eV in Fig. S3(c) corresponds to the O element of adsorbed water on the surface. The peak at near 531 eV is usually associated with defects created by oxygen vacancies (OV), and the peak at near 530 eV corresponds to the metal-O (M-O) peak. The Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO shows the largest area of OV, indicating the largest concentration of O vacancy on the surface. The reason for this phenomenon is that N and P atoms occupy positions originally belonging to O atoms, resulting in a higher concentration of O vacancies. P 2p XPS spectra indicates the presence of P–O and metal–P bonds on the P-NFO and Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO surface as shown in Fig. S3(d) [58]. The peaks in the N 1s XPS spectrum correspond to graphite-N and metal-Nx species, respectively, which implies that the N atoms were successfully doped into Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO and formed metal–N bonds with Ni and Fe (Fig. S3(e)) [59]. The catalytic activity and selectivity of the prepared Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO anode catalysts for the oxidation of PET solution were investigated in a three-electrode system under AM 1.5G simulated sunlight illumination (100 Mw cm–2). The PET electrolyte used contains TA, phthalate esters and glycol monomers, which were obtained by hydrolysis. Since TA and phthalates do not undergo any changes during the photoelectrocatalysis process, this photoelectrocatalysis process is dominated by the EGOR. Fig. 3(a) shows the linear scanning voltammetry (LSV) curves of the Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO catalyst with different P contents (mass percentage) in 1 mol L–1 KOH solution containing 0.1 mol L–1 PET under dark conditions. The results showed that when the phosphorus content was 9 at%, P-NFO had the best catalytic activity and the lowest overpotential. At 50 mA cm–2, the overpotential of Ni SAs/A-P0.09-N-NFO was 1.39 V. In addition, Ni SAs/A-P0.09-N-NFO exhibited the lowest Tafel slope (41.8 mV dec–1), which suggests a superior kinetic performance (Fig. 3(b)). The above results indicate that the moderate amount of P doping effectively improves the catalytic oxidation of PET solution by Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO. Fig. 3(c) illustrates the Faraday efficiency (FE) of Ni SAs/A-P0.09-N-NFO catalyst at the different potentials. Notably, the formic acid selectivity of Ni SAs/A-P0.09-N-NFO was greater than 85% (potential range is 1.3–1.7 V) and the formic acid selectivity at 1.5 V vs. RHE reached the highest value of 93%. The impedance values of the different samples were measured by using Nyquist plots and the Ni SAs/A-P0.09-N-NFO had the smallest impedance indicating that it had the fastest charge transfer rate and therefore the strongest catalytic activity (Fig. 3(d)). The transient photocurrent curves show that the Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO photoanodes have essentially unbiased photocurrents under illumination (Fig. S4(a)). The incident photon pair current efficiencies (IPCE) of Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO photoanodes at different potentials were measured and calculated as shown in Fig. S4(b). The IPCE value is about 1.6, and the characteristics of the amorphous structure cause the IPCE to decay faster, while the photocurrent density is 0.72 mA cm–2. The catalytic activity of Ni SAs/A-P0.09-N-NFO was further evaluated by LSV curves under different reaction conditions (Fig. 3(e)). Under dark conditions, the current density of the electrolyte containing PET is significantly higher at the same voltage. At 50 mA cm–2, the anodic overpotential of Ni SAs/A-P0.09-N-NFO in the PET solution was reduced by 200 mV compared to the solution without PET. Notably, in the solution containing PET, the overpotential decreased by 20 mV under light conditions compared to dark conditions, which proved that the catalytic activity of Ni SAs/A-P0.09-N-NFO anode catalyst could be effectively enhanced under light conditions. After the PEC process with an applied bias is 1.5 V vs. RHE, the composition of the PET solution was analysed by 1H NMR (Fig. 3(f)). The results show three peaks for ethylene glycol (~3.5 δ), D2O (~4.7 δ), and TPA (~7.69 δ), indicating the presence of all three substances in the solution after EGOR. The performance was tested in the absence of hydrolysis of PET in comparison. The results show that the LSV overpotential is high in the case of non-hydrolysed PET (Fig. S5(a)). In order to compare whether pure photocatalytic conditions have an effect on the POR, we placed the electrode system in the reaction solution under pure light conditions for 10 h. The 1H NMR results showed a high concentration of ethylene glycol and terephthalic acid in the products, whereas little formic acid and other products were produced, indicating that PET hydrolysate could not be converted under pure photocatalytic conditions (Fig. S5(b)). The 13C NMR spectrum (Fig. S5(c)) shows peaks for DMSO, ethylene glycol, terephthalic acid and formic acid. After the EC reaction, a peak for formic acid was evident in the reaction solution. After the PEC reaction, the peak intensity of formic acid in the reaction solution was higher, indicating a higher concentration of formic acid product. Meanwhile, the peak of terephthalic acid appeared, indicating that PEC can produce more organic products than EC [63]. In order to emphasize the role of the photothermal effect, a comparison was made between a circulating water system and a non-circulating water system. The temperature was controlled at 25 °C in the circulating water system, at which point the influence of the photothermal effect was shielded. The results of the LSV curves show that in the circulating water system, the effect of light makes the overpotential smaller than in the purely electrocatalytic condition. In the non-circulating water system, the overpotential was smaller, which proved that the photothermal effect could promote the reaction more (Figs. S5(d) and (e)). In addition, ultraviolet-visible diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UV-vis DRS) shows that the excitation wavelength of Ni SAs/A-P0.09-N-NFO becomes larger, and the band gap becomes narrower (Figs. 4(a) and (b) ), it benefits of photogenerated electron-hole pair separation. Photoluminescence (PL) spectra show that Ni SAs/A-P0.09-N-NFO displays a very low luminescence intensity, demonstrating a better photogenerated electron-hole pair separation ability (Fig. 4(c)). Changes in free radical concentration were determined by testing ESR spectra under dark and light conditions. In the ESR signals of photoanodic Ni SAs/A-P0.09-N-NFO, characteristic peaks of DMPO- •O2 − adducts and DMPO-•OH adducts were observed under visible light irradiation (Figs. 4(d) and (e)). The concentrations of •O2 − and •OH were significantly higher under light than under dark conditions, i.e., it was demonstrated that the •O2 − and •OH also played a role in redox reactions of PET hydrolysis products during the PEC process. The possible reaction process is as follows [64–66]: (1) A – P – NFO + hv → A – P – NFO (h+ + e–) (2) O2 + e– → •O2 − (3) 2H2O + 2h+ → •OH + 2H+ (4) H2O + •O2 − → •OOH + OH− (5) H+ + •OOH → •OH + OH− It is well known that the redox properties of •O2 − and •OH are excellent, so they can effectively convert the EG during the hydrolysis process, which also explains why the overpotential of LSV is lower and the catalytic activity is better under the light condition [67–69]. The essence is that the catalytic reaction is carried out with the help of “light + electricity” mode at the same time, which is more advantageous than the electrocatalytic process. Different radical trapping agents were incorporated to investigate the role of different types of radicals in the photoelectrocatalytic process. Among them, benzoquinone (BQ) was a superoxide radical trapping agent and tert-butanol (TBA) was a hydroxyl radical trapping agent. Under the light condition, the current densities of the two radical trapping agents significantly decreased after their addition, which implied that both radicals were involved in the oxidation process of EG during the reaction (Fig. 4(f)). In addition, when P-NFO and Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO were placed under light conditions, the warming rate of Ni SAs/A-P0.09-N-NFO was faster in the same time interval, suggesting that Ni SAs/A-P0.09-N-NFO has a better photothermal effect (Figs. 4(g1)–(h4)). It can be attributed to the improved excitation wavelength and bandgap after P doping, making the surface photogenerated electrons easier to be excited. It may also be due to the compounding of photogenerated electron-hole pairs, which causes a change in the surface temperature. The photothermal effect can significantly enhance the charge migration and surface reaction kinetics of the catalyst, further improving the catalytic performance. Therefore, Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO has better PEC EGOR catalytic performance [70,71]. To investigate the high catalytic activity of Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO catalysts and how the Ni-N3-P structure affects the catalytic activity of the surface during PET oxidation, a series of density functional theory (DFT) calculations were carried out. The surface charges of the three samples were compared using electron localization function (ELF) plots. Taking the (001) surface as an example, as shown in Fig. 5(a) , the charge concentration on the surface of Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO is significantly higher than that of C-NFO and P-NFO, indicating that the Ni-N3-P structure is more favorable for the charge transfer process, thereby accelerating the reaction rate. In addition, compared with those in C-NFO and P-NFO, the charge densities near the P-site and N-site in Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO are significantly higher, while those near the Ni-site and Fe-site are significantly lower. Because for the three atoms P, N, O, the electronegativity order is O > N > P, so the O atom has the strongest ability to attract electrons and the charge concentration around it is significantly higher. Compared with P-NFO and C-NFO, Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO has weaker Ni–O bond strength around the Ni site due to its amorphous structure, which makes it easier for the electrons around it to separate from Ni atoms, resulting in a lower charge density. Meanwhile, reducing the charge density around Ni and Fe sites will cause the chemical bonds around the two atoms to become unsaturated, which is more conducive to the adsorption of active species. This characteristic also allows Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO to generate more photo generated electrons under light conditions, thereby generating more free radicals to enhance EGOR activity. The d-band centers of three samples, Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO, P-NFO and C-NFO, were investigated using projected density of states (PDOS) to explain the adsorption capacity of the catalysts. The d-band centers of Ni and Fe in Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO are significantly shifted upwards and closer to the Fermi energy level than those of the P-NFO and C-NFO samples (Figs. 5(b), (c)). This indicates that Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO absorbs reactive species more easily during the EGOR process, which plays a key role in improving the catalytic activity. Usually, the oxidation of EG initially forms glycolaldehyde, which is subsequently oxidized to glycolic acid (GA), and based on this reaction pathway, the Gibbs free energies for the conversion of formate were calculated for the Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO, P-NFO and C-NFO three catalysts (Fig. S5(f)). The optimized structural models developed are shown in Figs. S6(a), (b). As shown in Fig. 5(d), the reaction energy barriers for the EGOR process in the presence of the Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO catalyst were lower than those of P-NFO and C-NFO. Therefore, Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO exhibits the best overall performance in the oxidation of formate. Throughout the electrooxidation of, the cleavage of the O–H bond of initially formed *CH2OHCHO as an intermediate, followed by the cleavage of the O–H bond and the C–H bond to produce the *CH2OHCO intermediate. During the surface cleavage of the O–H and C–H bonds in *CH2OHCHO to form the *CH2OHCO intermediate on Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO (1.07 eV), the resulting intermediate for adsorption of *CH2OHCHO Gibbs free energy is lower than that of C-NFO (1.25 eV) and P-NFO (1.14 eV). Taken together, these factors contribute to the superior performance of Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO [72,73]. In summary, there are two reasons for the good catalytic activity of Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO. On the one hand, the amorphous structure for the catalyst surface can provide more active sites and accelerate the transfer of electrons. On the other hand, the Ni-N3-P single-atom structure optimized the adsorption capacity on the Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO surface and reduced the adsorption energy of the intermediates during the EGOR process, thus improving the catalytic activity. In order to explore the reaction pathways and identify key reaction intermediates in EGOR, we performed potential-dependent in-situ Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) and in-situ Raman spectroscopic measurements of Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO. Fig. S7 illustrates the peaks of in-situ FTIR at 1386 and 1563 cm–1 observed over a potential range from OCP to 1.3 V (vs. RHE). These peaks correspond to the symmetric and asymmetric stretching bands of –COO in GA. The enhancement of these characteristic peaks with increasing potential suggests that a small amount of GA is generated during the oxidation of EG. The appearance of C-O stretching peak at 1236 cm−1 also indicates the production of GA. Meanwhile, the inverse absorption peak (–OH of EG) at 1461 cm–1 also enhanced with the increase in potential, indicating that EG was consumed. The presence of –COO signal peak at 1640 cm–1 also indicated the generation of FA. With further increase in potential, the intensity of the peak at 1640 cm–1 also enhanced gradually with the increase in potential, indicating a gradual increase in the concentration of FA [74–76]. Fig. S8 illustrates the peaks of the in-situ Raman results observed over a potential range from OCP to 1.3 V (vs. RHE). Firstly, since Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO is an amorphous structure, Ni and Fe on its surface will be more easily reconstructed to form MOOH (M = Ni and Fe) intermediates during the reaction process. The peak at 498 cm–1 corresponds to the peak of Ni in Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO that reconstructs to form NiOOH during the reaction process, and the peak at 685 cm–1 corresponds to the peak of Fe in Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO that reconstructs to form FeOOH during the reaction process. In addition, the peaks at 1090 cm–1 belonged to the special signal peaks of γ(C–O–H) of ethanoic acid, respectively, and the intensity of the peaks gradually increased with the increase of potential, indicating that EG in the product was hydrolysed gradually during the reaction [45,74]. To make full use of the photoelectrochemical cell, we also designed Ag nanoparticles (NPs) supported on CuO/Cu2O nanocubes (Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O NCs) as cathode catalyst to couple the reactions occurring at the anode. Firstly, uniform Cu2O nanocubes were synthesized using wet chemistry. Then the Ag source was added and mixed with Cu2O sufficiently, and the Ag nanoparticles were formed by using Cu+ to reduce Ag+, while Cu+ would form Cu2+ in this process, which in turn formed a mixed phase of CuO/Cu2O (the molar ratio of CuO and Cu2O was about 1:7 according to the XPS results). The final sample synthesized was named Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O nanocubes (Fig. 6(a) ). Specific synthesis methods and details are in the Supporting Information. SEM and TEM images show that the pristine Cu2O and Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O NCs appear in a cubic state. The lattice in the HRTEM images also corresponds to the lattice fringes of the Cu2O, which suggests that the crystalline phases have not been altered after loading Ag nanoparticles (Figs. 6(b)–(f)). Fig. 6(g) shows the AC-HAADF-STEM image, which shows that Ag nanoparticles with particle size of about 5 nm were loaded on the surface of Cu2O. The HAADF-STEM and EDX images and elemental mapping images show the uniform distributions of Ag, Cu, and O elements in Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O NCs (Fig. 6(h)). The XRD results of the prepared Cu2O and Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O NCs are in perfect agreement with the typical diffraction peaks of Cu2O (PDF #05-0677), and no other diffraction peaks appear after composite with Ag nanoparticles, indicating that the crystalline phase remains unchanged (Fig. S9). The electronic structure and elemental composition of Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O NCs were analyzed by XPS measurements. Fig. S10(a) shows the full XPS spectrum of Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O NCs, indicating the presence of Ag, Cu, and O elements. The Cu 2p 1/2 and Cu 2p 3/2 binding energies of Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O NCs were about 952.4 and 932.6 eV, respectively (Fig. S10(b)), which can be attributed to the characteristic peaks of Cu0 and Cu+ [77–79], which proves the existence of a 1-valent or 0-valent Cu. In addition, there exists a small signal peak at near 933.6 eV that corresponds to Cu2+ [80]. Based on the peak area calculation, Cu2+/Cu+ is about 1:7, i.e., the molar ratio of Cu2+ to Cu+ is 1:7. Fig. S10(c) exhibits the Ag 3d XPS spectra of Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O NCs. The two main peaks located at 368.2 and 374.3 eV are assigned to the binding energies of Ag 3d 5/2 and Ag 3d 3/2, respectively [81,82], which indicates that Ag is present in the form of positive 1-valent. The O 1s spectrum indicates the presence of oxygen vacancies in Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O NCs, which may be due to some lattice distortion within the lattice resulting from Ag hybridization, leading to the appearance of oxygen vacancies (Fig. S10(d)) [83,84]. The photoelectrocatalytic activity and selectivity of Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O NCs for CO2RR were investigated in three-electrode system under AM 1.5G simulated sunlight illumination (100 Mw cm−2). The CO2RR selectivity of Cu2O and Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O NCs was measured in the voltage range from −1 to −1.5V vs. RHE. Fig. 7(a) shows the selectivity of CO2RR for C2H4 at different potentials. The FEs generated from C2H4 gradually increase with increasing potential, which indicates that increasing potential can effectively inhibit H2 production and promote the hydrogenation reaction, thus increasing the FEs of C2H4. By comparing the selectivity at different potentials for Cu2O and Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O NCs, it was found that the selectivity of C2H4 reached its maximum at −1.5 V. The maximum FEs of C2H4 on Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O NCs and Cu2O were found to be 18 ± 3% and 5 ± 4%, respectively, at −1.5 V vs. RHE. Meanwhile, the selectivity of Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O NCs for C2H4 was higher than that of Cu2O at all potentials. At the same potential, the maximum FE of Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O NCs was 55 ± 4% for CO and 42 ± 4% for C2H4 when the reaction conditions were in the light. It is suggested that the escape of surface photogenerated electrons is more favorable to CO2RR under light conditions, thus improving the selectivity of C2H4. As shown in Fig. 7(b), Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O NCs exhibits greater current density in CO2RR than pure Cu2O at all studied potentials. It indicates that Ag nanoparticles accelerated the electron transfer process and improved catalytic activity during CO2RR. LSV curves of Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O NCs with different Ag contents were tested, and the best kinetic performance was obtained when the Ag mass percentage was 6 wt% (Fig. S11). In addition, the stability of the Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O NCs catalyst was evaluated by controlling potential at −1.5 V vs. RHE for 15 h (Fig. 7(c)). During the test, the current density gradually increased over the course of 9 h, eventually reaching and remaining around 9 mA cm−2, while the selectivity of C2H4 remained at 40 ± 3%. The comprehensive comparison of the selectivity of CO2RR products under light and dark conditions revealed that the photogenerated electrons on the surface of Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O NCs under light conditions effectively promoted the generation of C2H4 (Fig. 7(d)). The free energy diagrams of Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O NCs and Cu2O in the CO2RR reaction pathway are shown in Fig. 7(e). The optimized structural models developed are shown in Fig. S6(c) and (d). A model commonly used in previous theoretical studies was adopted to assess the reaction free energy at the CO2RR interface. CO2 is initially activated to form *CO, then hydrogenated to *CHO, then combined with *CO to form the key *CHOCO intermediate, and finally C2H4 through a series of energy decreasing processes. The critical energy barrier of Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O NCs adsorption and activation to *COOH is much lower, and therefore the CO2 reduction activity can be increased by shifting the selectivity from the hydrogen evolution reaction to the CO2 reduction pathway. After the formation of the *CHO intermediate, the absorbed *CHO attracts the approaching CO2 molecules for a second hydrogenation to form the *CHO + *COOH intermediate, which undergoes hydrogenation to produce the *CHO + *CO intermediate. Finally, *CHOCO undergoes self-coupling and hydrogenation to form C2H4. The rate-determining step for the generation of C2H4 on the surface of both catalysts is the C–C coupling step. The energy barrier for the change from *CHOCO to C2H4 on the Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O NCs surface (3.46 eV) is much lower than that on the pure Cu2O surface (3.76 eV). This indicates that in CO2RR, Ag doping makes the Cu2O surface more active for C–C coupling [11,84]. In view of the excellent catalytic performance of Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO and Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O, the photoelectrochemical cell was assembled with Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO as anode catalyst and Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O NCs as cathode catalyst for microplastic oxidation and CO2 reduction, and the PET conversion and CO2RR were measured (Fig. 8(a) ). Fig. S12 shows the photograph of the xenon lamp light source used. As shown in Fig. 8(b), the photoanode shows an overpotential of only 1.46 V vs RHE for PET oxidation at 50 mA cm–2 under light conditions, and the products were terephthalic acid and formic acid, with a selectivity of 93% for the target product formic acid at 1.46 V vs. RHE. The CO2RR performance of photocathode at different potentials was measured, and the products of the photocathode at a potential of 1 V vs. RHE was only CO, and CO selectivity reached 83%. At the potential of 1.2 V vs. RHE, the cathode products were CO and C2H4, with a selectivity of 77% for CO and 18% for C2H4. In addition, at a potential of 1.5 V vs. RHE, the cathode products were CO and C2H4, with a selectivity of 49% for CO and 41% for C2H4. Therefore, the photoelectrochemical cell composed of Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO as anode catalyst and Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O NCs as cathode catalyst shows great application prospects for microplastic oxidation and CO2 reduction. TEM, EDX, XRD and XPS of Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO after the PEC reaction were measured. The TEM and EDX images show that the structure still exhibits an amorphous structure and Ni, Fe, O, N, P are still present on the surface (Figs. S13(a), (b)). XPS shows that all elements except O are oxidized after the reaction, so they are all shifted in the direction of high binding energy. Since O may be consumed in the reaction to form hydroxyl radicals or superoxide radicals, the bonding strength of O with other elements is weakened and thus shifted to the low binding energy direction. XRD shows that the structure is still amorphous and remains unchanged after the reaction. In conclusion, the synthesized Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO photoanodes have good structural stability (Figs. S14(a)–(f)) [85]. 4 Conclusions In summary, we demonstrate a strategy to convert PET microplastics into high-value chemicals through PEC technology. The results demonstrate the feasibility and economic value of this strategy. The synthesized photoanode Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO has good catalytic activity and high Faraday efficiency (93%) during PET upgrading process. The photocathode has high syngas selectivity during CO2RR with 97% FEs for CO and C2H4. In the PEC system, the photocathode and photoanode still maintained high catalytic activity for PET conversion and CO2RR, respectively. Moreover, the catalysts for PEC systems are synthesized from elements that are abundant on the earth, which implies a low production cost and has the prospect of mass production. This work provides inspiration and feasible strategies for the recycling of microplastics, and innovative ideas for designing low-cost catalysts to convert CO2 into high value-added chemicals. coredata.dc:description: Plastics are ubiquitous in human life and pose certain hazards to the environment and human body. The increasing amount of CO2 in the atmosphere will lead to the greenhouse effect. Therefore, it is urgent to treat microplastic waste and CO2 by using environmentally friendly and efficient technologies. In this work, we developed an efficient photoelectrocatalytic system composed of Ni single atoms (Ni SAs) supported by P, N-doped amorphous NiFe2O4 (Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO) as anode and Ag nanoparticles (Ag NPs) supported by CuO/Cu2O nanocubes (Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O NCs) as cathode for microplastic oxidation and CO2 reduction. The Ni SAs/A-P-N-NFO was synthesized by calcination-H2 reduction method, and it achieved a Faraday efficiency of 93% for the oxidation reaction of poly (ethylene terephthalate) (PET) solution under AM 1.5 G light. As a photocathode, the synthesized Ag NPs@CuO/Cu2O NCs was utilized to reduce CO2 to ethylene and CO at 1.5 V vs. RHE with selectivity of 42% and 55%, respectively. This work shows that the photoelectrocatalysis, as an environmentally friendly technology, is a feasible strategy for reducing the environmental and biological hazards of light plastics, as well as for efficient CO2 reduction.
